books.title: To Kill a Mockingbird
books.author: Harper Lee
books.summary: To Kill a Mockingbird is a novel by Harper Lee published in 1960. It is set in the fictional town of Maycomb, Alabama, and follows the story of Atticus Finch, a lawyer, as he defends a black man accused of raping a white woman.

books.author: George Orwell
books.summary: 1984 is a dystopian novel by George Orwell published in 1949. The story takes place in a totalitarian society where the government, led by the Party and its leader Big Brother, exercises total control over its citizens.

books.title: The Great Gatsby
books.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
books.summary: The Great Gatsby is a novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald published in 1925. Set in the Jazz Age on Long Island, the story follows the mysterious Jay Gatsby and his pursuit of wealth and love.

books.title: Pride and Prejudice
books.author: Jane Austen
books.summary: Pride and Prejudice is a novel by Jane Austen published in 1813. It follows the story of Elizabeth Bennet as she navigates issues of manners, upbringing, morality, education, and marriage in the society of the landed gentry of the British Regency.

books.title: The Catcher in the Rye
books.author: J.D. Salinger
books.summary: The Catcher in the Rye is a novel by J.D. Salinger published in 1951. It is known for its protagonist, Holden Caulfield, a cynical and rebellious teenager, as he navigates through the challenges of adolescence and adulthood.

books.title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
books.author: J.K. Rowling
books.summary: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (released in the United States as Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone) is a fantasy novel by J.K. Rowling published in 1997. It follows the journey of young wizard Harry Potter as he discovers his magical heritage.

books.title: The Hobbit
books.author: J.R.R. Tolkien
books.summary: The Hobbit, or There and Back Again, is a fantasy novel by J.R.R. Tolkien published in 1937. It follows the quest of the hobbit Bilbo Baggins to win a share of the treasure guarded by the dragon Smaug.

books.title: The Lord of the Rings
books.author: J.R.R. Tolkien
books.summary: The Lord of the Rings is an epic fantasy novel by J.R.R. Tolkien published in the mid-20th century. It tells the story of the quest to destroy the Dark Lord Sauron's One Ring.

books.title: Moby-Dick
books.author: Herman Melville
books.summary: Moby-Dick; or, The Whale is an epic novel by Herman Melville published in 1851. It tells the story of Ishmael's voyage aboard the whaling ship Pequod, commanded by Captain Ahab, who is obsessed with hunting the giant white sperm whale known as Moby Dick.

books.title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland
books.author: Lewis Carroll
books.summary: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland is a novel by Lewis Carroll published in 1865. It tells the story of a young girl named Alice who falls through a rabbit hole into a fantasy world populated by peculiar creatures.

books.title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe
books.author: C.S. Lewis
books.summary: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe is a fantasy novel by C.S. Lewis published in 1950. It is the first published and best known of seven novels in The Chronicles of Narnia series.

books.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
books.author: Oscar Wilde
books.summary: The Picture of Dorian Gray is a Gothic and philosophical novel by Oscar Wilde, first published complete in the July 1890 issue of Lippincott's Monthly Magazine. The novel tells the story of young Dorian Gray, who becomes enthralled by his own portrait and wishes to remain young forever, leading to tragic consequences.

books.title: Jane Eyre
books.author: Charlotte Brontë
books.summary: Jane Eyre is a novel by English writer Charlotte Brontë, published under the pen name "Currer Bell", on 16 October 1847, by Smith, Elder & Co. of London. The novel follows the story of a young orphan named Jane Eyre as she grows up, faces various trials and tribulations, and eventually finds love and independence.

books.title: Frankenstein
books.author: Mary Shelley
books.summary: Frankenstein; or, The Modern Prometheus is a novel written by English author Mary Shelley, published anonymously in 1818. It tells the story of Victor Frankenstein, a young scientist who creates a sapient creature in an unorthodox scientific experiment.

books.title: Wuthering Heights
books.author: Emily Brontë
books.summary: Wuthering Heights is a novel by Emily Brontë, first published in 1847 under the pseudonym Ellis Bell. It is her only finished novel. It follows the passionate and tempestuous love story of Heathcliff and Catherine Earnshaw against the backdrop of the Yorkshire moors.

books.title: Brave New World
books.author: Aldous Huxley
books.summary: Brave New World is a dystopian novel by Aldous Huxley, published in 1932. It imagines a futuristic world state that has achieved peace and stability through the prohibition of monogamy, privacy, money, family, and history itself.

books.title: The Odyssey
books.author: Homer
books.summary: The Odyssey is one of two major ancient Greek epic poems attributed to Homer. It is, in part, a sequel to the Iliad, the other Homeric epic. The poem is fundamental to the modern Western canon, and it is the second-oldest extant work of Western literature, the Iliad being the oldest.

books.title: The Iliad
books.author: Homer
books.summary: The Iliad is an ancient Greek epic poem in dactylic hexameter, traditionally attributed to Homer. Set during the Trojan War, the ten-year siege of the city of Troy by a coalition of Greek states, it tells of the battles and events during the weeks of a quarrel between King Agamemnon and the warrior Achilles.

books.title: The Alchemist
books.author: Paulo Coelho
books.summary: The Alchemist is a novel by Brazilian author Paulo Coelho that was first published in 1988. Originally written in Portuguese, it became an international bestseller translated into many languages. The novel follows the journey of an Andalusian shepherd named Santiago as he travels from his homeland in Spain to the Egyptian desert in search of a treasure buried near the Pyramids.

books.title: The Count of Monte Cristo
books.author: Alexandre Dumas
books.summary: The Count of Monte Cristo is an adventure novel by French author Alexandre Dumas, first serialized in 1844–1846. It is often considered, along with The Three Musketeers, as Dumas' most popular work. The story takes place in France, Italy, and islands in the Mediterranean during the historical events of 1815–1839: the era of the Bourbon Restoration through the reign of Louis-Philippe of France.

books.title: The Brothers Karamazov
books.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
books.summary: The Brothers Karamazov is a passionate philosophical novel set in 19th-century Russia, that enters deeply into the ethical debates of God, free will, and morality. It is a spiritual drama of moral struggles concerning faith, doubt, and reason, set against a modernizing Russia.

books.title: Crime and Punishment
books.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
books.summary: Crime and Punishment is a novel by the Russian author Fyodor Dostoevsky. It was first published in the literary journal The Russian Messenger in twelve monthly installments during 1866. The novel deals with the mental anguish and moral dilemmas of Rodion Raskolnikov, an impoverished ex-student in Saint Petersburg who formulates a plan to kill an unscrupulous pawnbroker for her money.

books.title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
books.author: Gabriel García Márquez
books.summary: One Hundred Years of Solitude is a landmark 1967 novel by Colombian author Gabriel García Márquez that tells the multi-generational story of the Buendía family, whose patriarch, José Arcadio Buendía, founded the town of Macondo, a fictitious town in the country of Colombia.

books.title: The Bell Jar
books.author: Sylvia Plath
books.summary: The Bell Jar is the only novel by the American writer and poet Sylvia Plath. Originally published under the pseudonym "Victoria Lucas" in 1963, the novel is semi-autobiographical, with the names of places and people changed. The story follows a young woman's mental breakdown and eventual recovery, while interning at a magazine in New York City.

books.title: The Stranger
books.author: Albert Camus
books.summary: The Stranger is a novel by Albert Camus, published in 1942. Its theme and outlook are often cited as examples of Camus's philosophy, absurdism, and existentialism. The protagonist, Meursault, is an indifferent Algerian Frenchman who refuses to conform to societal expectations.
